Comment: White is opening with 1.e4, wich says a little bit about his style. Most e4-players like open, tactical positions..
I'm heading for my normal response to 1.e4; the Caro-Kann.
Ok, white chooses for the Advance-variation of the Caro-Kann. By advancing his e-pawn to e5, he's gaining space, and in meanwhile he's countering my development.
Ok, white chooses for the Advance-variation of the Caro-Kann. By advancing his e-pawn to e5, he's gaining space, and in meanwhile he's countering my development.
Ok, white chooses for the Advance-variation of the Caro-Kann. By advancing his e-pawn to e5, he's gaining space, and in meanwhile he's countering my development.

First of all, my bishop needs to get out of the back rank. f5 is a good spot to take a rest.
By playing 3. ... Bf5, we're reaching the Short-variation in the Advanced Caro-Kann.
All book-moves. These are "natural" opening-moves. We now see that white takes control of the most black squares in the center, and black controls the white center-fields.
All book-moves. These are "natural" opening-moves. We now see that white takes control of the most black squares in the center, and black controls the white center-fields.
All book-moves. These are "natural" opening-moves. We now see that white takes control of the most black squares in the center, and black controls the white center-fields.
By closing the pawn-chain, we now have a solid pawn-structure for black.
A normal developing move; white is preparing to castle kingside.

I played this move to get a response ready for the case white plays Qb3, threatening to take my b-pawn. If white does that right now, I have the answer Qb6. After a possible exchange of queens, my knight would be nicely placed on b6.
Bringing his King to safety; normal procedure..
Preparing the moves Ne7 going to Ng6. In this manner, the opponent can't play Bg5, pinning my knight in front of my Queen.
Well, maybe this wasn't the move I would play if I where white.. I'd rather go for a b3-c4 pawn-storm.
I'm leaving my options open.. This knight can go to g6, as well as f5 and c6 (once the c-pawn is advanced).

Ok, white is trying to make some open lines. A good idea ! 
The thing is, I can't let him play 10. c5, because my black bishop would be enclosed.
So, let's make some room for my pieces ! See how the important d5-squares is coming free ? That would be a nice outpost for my knight !
Developing and attacking at the same time..
Developing and attacking at the same time..
White's plan is to create pressure on b7. But black isn't in a hurry, there's time to develop my pieces.
Must be played in order to save the bishop. If black plays 12. Be3 Nxe3 13. fxe3, white would've created an open line in front of his rook on f1. So I'm not going to do that, yet..
Must be played in order to save the bishop. If black plays 12. Be3 Nxe3 13. fxe3, white would've created an open line in front of his rook on f1. So I'm not going to do that, yet..
Developing to the only square that's possible at the moment, though it's a good position for that bishop !
He's willing to do something on my d5-stronghold !
Protecting b7 and giving my king the opportunity to castle wich side he wants; either kingside or queenside..
